overview.short: Actinobacillus species are small, Gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic coccobacilli belonging to the Pasteurellaceae family, commonly associated with mucosal surfaces.
overview.clinical_context: Primarily associated with respiratory tract infections, oral infections, and invasive disease in both humans and animals.

field_notes.Shape: Often described as coccobacilli or short rods; may appear pleomorphic.
field_notes.Growth Requirements: Many species require enriched media and may grow poorly on MacConkey Agar.
field_notes.Oxidase: Reaction varies by species and is not genus-defining.

key_differentiators.notes: Poor or absent growth on MacConkey Agar helps separate Actinobacillus from Enterobacterales.
Non-motility helps differentiate from motile non-fermenters.
Helps separate Actinobacillus from some closely related Pasteurellaceae.

common_confusions.reason: Shared family Pasteurellaceae, similar morphology, and overlapping growth requirements.
Similar clinical niche and biochemical overlap, particularly in oral infections.

when_to_question_identification: Strong oxidase positivity and motility suggest Achromobacter or other non-fermenters.
Robust growth on MacConkey Agar argues against Actinobacillus.
Indole-positive isolates require careful species-level confirmation.

recommended_next_tests.test: Growth factor requirement testing (X and V factors)
recommended_next_tests.reason: Helps differentiate Actinobacillus from Haemophilus species.
Useful for species-level discrimination within Pasteurellaceae.
Reliable genus and species-level identification due to phenotypic overlap.
